Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Collaborative: Data Driven Post-Disaster Waste and Debris Volume Predictions using Smartphone Photogrammetry App and Unmanned Aerial Vehicles

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this proposal is to leverage photogrammetry from smart phones and unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) to automate the quantification of waste debris. In the aftermath of Hurricane Harvey and associated rainfall-induced flooding, a significant volume of waste and debris will be generated, especially in urban areas such as Houston and Beaumont, Texas. The management of post-disaster debris is an important issue faced by local and federal authorities: it contributes a significant portion of disaster management costs, can generate several times the annual waste generation rates of the affected community, and leads to higher expenditures due to error prone initial debris estimations. The current process to predict debris volume is inaccurate and inefficient, as it utilizes qualitative data from visual observation. The results of this study will improve the calibration of the flood debris estimation models by measuring debris generation due to Hurricane Harvey. This will aid in decision-making tools that ultimately will result in faster and more cost-effective debris management operations for future rainfall, tropical storm, and hurricane-induced flood events that continue to impact the Gulf, the US, and elsewhere around the world.

This RAPID project addresses the lack of post-disaster debris volume dataset by collecting ephemeral data through an automated smartphone photogrammetric app and UAV in Beaumont and other affected regions in Texas, and making the data available through open-source cyber-infrastructure databases. Debris volumes will be quantified by exploring the use of smartphones to automate the quantification of waste debris. In particular, smart phone images captured by the monitor, resident, or local government agency can be processed and scaled to develop a 3-D rendition and an estimate of waste volumes. These estimations will be validated using an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) photogrammetry surveys and which in turn can be converted using volumetric studies as well as other available debris volumes documented by monitoring companies. If successful, smartphones and UAVs can be quickly used in future natural disasters to analyze and characterize the digital images and then accurately quantify waste debris volumes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the aftermath of Hurricane Harvey and associated rainfall-induced flooding, significant volume of waste and debris was generated, especially in urban areas such as Houston and Beaumont, Texas. The management of post-disaster debris is an important issue faced by local and federal authorities because it is a major component of disaster management costs and can generate approximately an order of magnitude more waste than the annual waste generation rates of the affected community. The current process of documenting waste debris volumes is purely qualitative, i.e., based on visual observation. For example, the collection and disposal procedure involves the monitoring company to scan the truck barcode, tag the location, and identify the waste type. A ticket is provided to the truck driver, who transports the waste to a landfill. The monitoring company has another individual in a tower at the landfill who collects the ticket, peers into the truck bed, and writes the percent of truck bed filled. Therefore, how can estimates of debris volume collected at the curbside be automated to ensure reimbursement integrity? The aim of this RAPID grant was to quantify perishable waste debris volumes by leveraging photogrammetry from smartphones and unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV). 

The intellectual merit of this RAPID grant involved collecting perishable waste debris volumes in Beaumont, Texas, interacting with the City of Beaumont Emergency Operations Center, and compiling landfill waste debris tickets. The specific outcomes of this work include visiting eight (8) locations across Beaumont to document waste debris stockpiles. The UAV technology provided estimates of the stockpile volumes, which were compared to predictions from the smartphone. In general, the smartphone photogrammetry analyses indicated that a 3-Dimensional rendering of the stockpile is feasible but the predictions were greater than the UAV estimates, which is likely attributed to insufficient markers in the photos to delineate actual dimensions of objects. More accurate predictions are attainable with better planning. The research team also met with the Beaumont Emergency Operations Center (EOC) and Solid Waste Management teams to discuss strategies for waste collection and documentation of damage to physical infrastructure. In particular, the EOC were early adopters of UAVs to locate damage to roads, water and waste treatment plants, and power grids. The research teams also collected the printed landfill tickets, which were subsequently digitized into a database to better understand the logistics of waste generation, collection, and disposal.

The results of this study are expected to contribute to better processes for measuring waste debris volumes after natural disasters. Moreover, better data will significantly advance flood debris estimation models (e.g., HAZUS-MH) by measuring flood damage and debris generation during an extraordinary (1-in-1,000 year) event such as Hurricane Harvey. Better prediction models can used in comprehensive policy evaluation phases by both local and federal emergency management agencies (FEMA and USACE) for future event planning. This will aid in decision-making tools that ultimately will result in faster and more cost-effective debris management operations for future rainfall, tropical storm, and hurricane-induced flood events that continue to impact the Gulf, the US, and elsewhere around the world.
